comments.commentBody: Kay, there are laws that prohibit an employer from refusing to give you the benefits based on gender or race. Transfusion is a medical procedure, and that is covered in insurance. Supremes ruled that this narrow exception granted to 'closely held' corporations does not allow anyone to discriminate on any other basis. So, your argument is not well informed and you are thinking with your heart, not with your brains. You can do better.

That extra money would come if we all paid Medicare taxes and all received Medicare, rendering the substantial yet unsubstantiated difference available to employers as additional income, to purchase additional health care or insurance, or spend on cars, groceries, and houses.  Or expand business and hire more folks.   Like our international competition does, winning at a game we set up but seem determined to lose.  All for principle.   Hail, Columbia!

I would agree that most liberals see benefits as some sort of weird additional salary.  As an employer, I offer benefits to my employees (both American and Canadian) but still reserve the right to add/remove/delete benefits as I see fit.  I'm the one paying for it, so I get to decide (actually my HR and Finance groups make most of the decisions now).  If my employees don't want me to make the decisions, then they are free to use their own money.  In which case I won't say a word.

Hobby Lobby's religious views are apparently so "strongly held" that before the ACA came along they didn't even think twice - their insurance covered the very subject of their law suit.  This wasn't about religion, it was just another way to undermine the ACA.  Let's hope this accelerates Medicare-for-All so we can consign private health insurance to the dustbin of history.
The Supreme Court stepped in it this time...

Congress, rather. If the legislative and executive branches collude to grant religious carve-outs to laws that apply to the rest of us -- and they have, not just the RFRA but elsewhere, too -- then courts are bound by those laws unless they have sufficient grounds to invalidate them.

RFRA is a huge offender, but for instance there's also that whole "doesn't have to file Form 990s" for religious non-profit organizations that makes it much more difficult to determine whether they're just funneling everything to the head minister's favorite car dealership. One law for religious groups, one for the rest of us.
So are you saying that the US is a backwater on rights and privacy? What's next - reinstating slavery?

The ugliest part of this whole thing is not "religion"...they DO have "contraceptives" in their portfolio!

http://www.forbes.com/sites/rickungar/2014/04/01/hobby-lobby-401k-discov...

Corporations now have free speech and protected religious beliefs. Shall we move on to affirming their 2nd amendment right to bear arms? If a corporation, say, in Florida, feels its life threatened by another corporation, will the first corporation be within its rights to 'stand its ground' and use an appropriately sized weapon to defend itself against the perceived threat?

At what point will this 'corporations are people, my friend' legal absurdity stop?
I'm starting to hope we're one step closer to revolution.
And this privately-held company does business with China--unbothered by China's take on abortion.  But that's not a problem, right?
90% of working females will be affected by this.  Until the taxpayers are somehow coerced into paying for their birth control, they'll have to sadly buy their own.

Theism's traditional conception of God is an easy target. Thus it is usually the target of the "same people" you mention. They seem to be too poorly read to know that theistic belief, like everything else done and thought by human beings, has evolved, especially in the last 100 years or so.

Some who deny the idea of "God" nevertheless allow for some kind of deep purpose or destiny to the universe, possibly even one that dignifies our existence. Purpose and destiny are words that imply a consciousness. Once you start thinking along those lines you may be thinking theistically.

In my opinion, the reasoning ability of both academic philosophers and physicists about such questions as "Why do things exist?" and "Why is there something rather than nothing?" is mostly pathetic and laughable.  On one hand, you have physicists who think you can answer "Why is there something rather than nothing?" by assuming a "nothing" where the laws of quantum physics  still exist.  That's not the absolute nothing being thought of in the question and everyone except them seems to know it.  On the other hand, there are philosophers who talk so much about the history and merits of these questions that they don't try to answer the questions themselves.  And, on both sides, you have both physicists and philosophers who base their reasoning on a Platonic realm that no one can see, touch or test and that they can't point out.  And yet, these same people make fun of religious theists.  While I'm a biochemist by day, I'm an amateur philosopher by night, and I'm trying my best to actually reason out possible solutions to these questions, but people like me and other amateurs are derided by the above academics as crackpots.  Most of us are, but not all of us, and from what I can see, many or most of the academics are pretty crank-like themselves in their reasoning.
Yes - or your liver transplant......
We ain't seen nothin' yet.  We will have to go through the refiner's fire.
Probably the worst catalog of decisions ever laid down for this nation.
Ask old Ruth Ginsburg to step down; that's your best shot.  She refuses to do so, thus far.

As I near retirement, I am saddened  by the fact that the Roberts Court will outlive me. At some point in the future, I hope historians look upon this court as a dark period in the history of the SCOTUS.

Fertility certainly does lead to morbidity and mortality.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maternal_death

Can you seriously believe otherwise?
Never shopped there, never will.
The sword of the Supreme Court has tossed out the scalpels of the abortionists.  America's babies gurgle to say, "Thank you, SCOTUS!"  (Actually, the wee bairn gurgle it.)

It has become increasingly plain that this Court sees the First Amendment not as a Shield, but as a Sword.

And unfortunately for all of us, We The People are not wielding this weapon ... corporations and monied interests are.
No employee should have to put up with so called "religious beliefs" at the workplace, much less within the larger community in which they live. Your "belief" does not trump anyone's rights.

Not sure if you meant to have Michael to say 'and' - but, under the rules of logical construction, 'or' includes 'and' (i.e. one, or the other but doesn't exclude 'both') but 'and' does not include 'or'.  Just thought I'd throw that in - it's easier than thinking about the awful rationale used to come to the conclusion.  I've already posted several responses - now I gotta quit - other projects to absorb my time!
Wow.  That's the very basic question, isn't it?  Thank you.
Not mutually exclusive. Could be both. Usually is.
Ignorant or evil?

Wonderful article! It's what I've been doing implicitly--but it really helps to make it an explicit principle.

Being around and explicitly not being available is great, especially with older preschoolers and elementary students. My kids (ages 5 and 7) are great at amusing themselves for hours while I work from home. That unstructured time is really important: it's not all about adult engagement or structured classes! They've learned that there are times when I do my activities, and they do theirs--and other times when we play or work together, and our family is better for it.

More on the value of just letting the children shape their own activities, uninterrupted by adults: http://leportschools.com/blog/value-unstructured-time-instead-of-tv/

I believe Hobby Lobby is not against all contraceptives just IUDs which do "kill" a beginning embryo that has implanted itself on the uterine wall. It would be A OK with HL to use oral contraceptives, the sponge, condoms, etc.

You've got it backwards. Some people are so hostile to abortion rights that they are willing to deny women access to basic health care that has nothing to do with abortion, and may have nothing to do with contraception (i.e., the Mirena IUD, used by women with heavy periods to prevent anemia), and willing to support a court decision that may lead to corporations defunding blood transfusions, psychiatric care, etc, as mentioned by Ginsburg in her dissent:

"Would the exemption…extend to employers with religiously grounded objections to blood transfusions (Jehovah's Witnesses); antidepressants (Scientologists); medications derived from pigs, including anesthesia, intravenous fluids, and pills coated with gelatin (certain Muslims, Jews, and Hindus); and vaccinations[?]…Not much help there for the lower courts bound by today's decision."

They are not funding some of the most effective forms of birth control because they erroneously think that they cause the abortion of a fertilized egg.  I am looking at photographs right now of full fledged babies in the posters of the anti-abortion protesters as I write.  The birth control involved prevents the implantation of a single cell, something that happens naturally on a regular basis.  There is every reason to think that low paid workers at Hobby Lobby may not be ready financially for a family and may want the most effective birth control available, something they may not be able to afford on their own.  That is why we have health insurance.

"Hopefully the same-sex 'marriages', which are of course a contradiction in terms, will go the same way."

Don't hold your breath on that one.
